displayed_text: Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: So the sense is - is this therapy fixing the And are you worse for wear? I can’t really say from how you’re feeling you’re worse; so we talked last time. You know you had scans, Patient: And Doctor: So the scans are to show more cancer or; the last there was more sclerosis. We’re looking for new Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: So it’s obvious if you’re falling apart; it’s obvious if your scan showed more spots. Patient: Right. Okay. Doctor: So those are the two things that we’re really looking for. You also could say I also don’t want to do this anymore; I don’t like my numbers. You know I still have to get the pictures just to prove okay you came off because you don’t like being on the drug. You came off because your PSA was rising, you know it’s typically from a protocol perspective, he’s coming off because he’s feeling worse, his scan’s worse. Patient: Right. Doctor: He’s coming off because his scans are worse and his PSA is higher. Patient: Right. And I don’t have Doctor: So I’m comfortable going another month because I know that scans and by your lab tests and what you’ve told me about how you feel. And my sense is you should stay the course. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Okay. So, are we, or why, are we trying these other things because - and it could be both answers - because you want to know? Or because, they’re the most effective options for me? Doctor: So. (Pause) Patient: I don’t want to compromise your ethical considerations. Doctor: So, in the realm of standard treatment, the two treatments that we have that are new hormonal treatments, we call them “Second Line Treatments.” So, the, the Lupron/Eligard is the first one. We would add a second one. Both of those have been tested in big clinical trials, and both of those showed an improvement in survival for a large group of men. It wasn’t a huge improvement. Um. But it reduced your risk of dying of prostate cancer by about thirty percent. The survival improvement was on the order of months, but that is really, uh, for the whole group. It’s hard to call the individuals outta that. Um, so that’s kind of the baseline that we know. Um. And, those drugs, you know, they have side effects that we need to manage, but that’s kind of would be the next treatment that’s standard treatment. It’s approved by the FDA because of the survival improvement. The new finding about this new drug, they’re called “PARP” inhibitors. A group did a study in England where they had fifty guys who had some DNA mutation, mostly BRCA2. They treated the fifty guys; sixteen had mutations. And, they found that none of the people without the mutations responded. Fourteen of the sixteen - so, you know, ninety percent who had a mutation responded to these drugs very well. Suggesting, they’re probably going to work really well in patients like that. Um. Patient: Am I one of those people? Doctor: Yeah, you’re one of those people. Now, that drug hasn’t been through the big paces of FDA trial approval. That’s where it is right now. So, the trials we’re looking at are looking at giving that drug alone or in combination with these standard hormones. So, the trial that I would consider for you have multiple arms. We could talk about that in detail, but, it’s there’s two different trials they could either combine the drugs or give you one drug. Um. But, the, but the, where the field is moving is there’s going to be fifty trials of this to try to nail this down. Family Member: Now, you said immuno--- Doctor: So, the other thing that’s a little further back in time Patient: But, did you say multiple “harms?” Doctor: Hormones. Patient: Hormones. Okay. Doctor: So, one of the trials is you get --

Patient: No. I still wake up a couple of times a night you know and go but uh other than that I’m pretty active, play golf a couple of times a week. You know? Nothing slows me down. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I don’t have any bone pain. Don’t have any muscle pain per se. Uh. Doctor: So today we’re just going to go over stuff. And I, I mean it looks like unfortunately there’s been some changes that probably we’ll, we will have to call off the study. Patient: Oh is that right? Doctor: Yeah. Uh so the PSA to start with went up just a little, uh, so. Patient: It’s up around forty something isn’t it? Family Member: Six. Doctor: So it was forty-six, forty-three, forty-nine. So that’s almost the same number to me, maybe a little bit elevated from the last time. And then uh the bone scan we did looks pretty much the same. There’s really nothing new. Uh they’re seeing this bone spot they saw before, looks about the same. Uh they thought they saw a spot on the left side of your sternum. Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Well that’s been there for- Doctor: Yeah. So that, that really, they don’t really see anything new. So the only thing that’s changed is you have a couple of lymph nodes in the abdomen, pelvis that are, got a little bit bigger. Patient: Oh they have gotten? Doctor: Yeah. So uh so they looked along the aorta which is the main focus for down the body.

Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: It turns out that the genetic material of the cancer cell, which is called the DNA. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: - in order for that cancer cell to be able to replicate itself, to cause you know two cells from one and then four cells, eight cells, it needs to be able to replicate its DNA and then replicate itself after that. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And it turns out when you give high doses of testosterone in the setting where that cell has previously been in a low testosterone environment - Patient: Okay. Doctor: It causes the DNA molecules in the cell, the genetic material of the cancer cell, to break into smaller pieces. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So the DNA molecule basically shatters into these small pieces and that damage is so catastrophic that the cell is unable to fix those DNA breaks and because the DNA molecule has been broken up into small little pieces, that cell can’t replicate itself and it dies. Patient: Oh! Doctor: So that’s the theoretical mechanism. Patient: Uh huh.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So often we think of bone as being, we have this sort of feeling that bone is worse, but mostly because we just have trouble imaging and seeing how it changes. So, uh, but it also affects some of the trials we have because those trials require biopsies of tumor tissue, and it’s really hard to get tumor tissue from the bone. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So it may alter what we can do in terms of trials. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So today, I thought we could talk a little bit about kind of what the standard things are to do next, and then we could talk a little bit about some trials that we have. The typical thing we would do next is either to put you on another hormone- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, so you’d be on the shot and a pill. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, we talked before about there’s a drug called, Zytiga, and a drug called, Xtandi. Uh, they both could, could work very well, uh, and they’re both associated with improving survival in men who get the drugs. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: The main side effect of both is fatigue. Patient: Um hum.

Patient: I did. Doctor: Yeah, so it’s- Patient: Yeah, I, I, when they, they said I had phlebotomy, I asked if it was fasting, and they said “No.” So, I, uh, ate breakfast. Doctor: And your PSA today is twenty-two. Patient: Ouch. Doctor: That’s all good. And your testosterone is (pause6sec) Patient: Okay. Question. Sixteen to seventeen, and I don’t know the time frame that it went from sixteen to seventeen, but in (cell phone rings) Doctor: Yeah, don’t read much into it. You know, we’re just checking it more often. Patient: Well, I understand that, but what does that mean to the aggressiveness of the cancer? Does it - Doctor: Okay. Yeah, I mean my sense is that people who, let’s - I don’t have prostate cancer that I know of right now - but, if my PSA was going up and I don’t have the diagnosis, it sort of tells me if it’s going up that fast that I’m more likely when I put a needle in it to find bad cancer. So, we already know you’ve got bad cancer. Patient: Yeah. So, this is, doesn’t tell you. Doctor: Doesn’t tell you. Patient: Then, why do I keep getting stuck?

Family Member: So it’s a monthly, a monthly thing? Doctor: So the treatment you actually take every single day, so, the pills, so what you what you do usually is that you come in, we make sure that you're taking you after usually fill out a drug diary so that we see how many like if you're missing days, you take the pills, and then we would give you refills of the pills. Family Member: Okay, so will there be a blood test when he comes back also? Doctor: Yeah. Not every single time. Family Member: oh OKAY. And how long is this trial for? Doctor: This one, I think it's for two years so that you can, you can stay on it. You can stay on it for two years. Usually, if people are getting benefit, and they're still on it, then usually we can work with the company to continue it. Even though technically the study ends. But that's not always the case. Technically. I mean, usually, that's not always the case. Family Member: But the study itself is for two years. Doctor: Yes, yes. Yes, yes. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: All right. So let me, um yeah, so this is the so this is the part that's part of the research that's going to be free of charge. So right now what we'll do is the blood for this is the specific gene that we're looking for. And then if you join the study, and you have the right genotype, we'll get all of these and then these other things are not part of their like part of standard treatment. So those don't get paid for by the study they get paid for by your insurance company as normal. Patient: By insurance. Doctor: So if you are okay with this, I will get your signature there and then. You have to put the time. Time is 450

Family Member 2: So you don’t have any more questions K___? Family Member: I don’t think so. (Laughs) Doctor: Yeah I know, she said that. Family Member 2: We’re glad that she was able to come. Doctor: Yeah, no that’s wonderful. Yeah it’s important to… What do you think or are you ready to bail from this treatment? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You are. Okay. No that’s critical information that I need to know (laughs) Family Member 2: He doesn’t like the trips. Doctor: I know, know. Patient: Yeah, that’s the thing. Family Member 2: It’s, it’s, it’s, it’s you know, now it’s only like every three weeks so… Doctor: Yeah it’s not too bad.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Sound good? Patient: Thank you again. Doctor: Tell them before the end of July because I’m taking off June and July I’m having hip surgery. Patient: Oh okay. Doctor: So I’ll be seeing you though towards the end of July. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Did you want to see him before we go? Healthcare Professional: Yes I do.

Patient: Oh, tailgate with my college football friends. It was homecoming. Doctor: Okay, you’re making me work hard Mr. S____. You know what we have to do? We have to repeat your scans anyways because it’s time. You’re last one was July. Patient: My what scan? Doctor: Your CAT scan/bone scan just to see what’s going on. I’m not sure that the leg’s anything. You know, sometimes it’s a red herring like hey, I’ve been driving and I was partying and then it kind of hurt. We’re always perpetually paranoid about clots. You know that. Any type of blood clot. But I don’t think you have that because normally it shows up in our lower legs and our calves and your calves are as skinny as they come so and they don’t hurt and they’re not swollen so we’ll leave it there. But that leg, you know, we always have to fuss about because we know your bone scan can change at any time. I know we finished chemo but it might be time to figure out what else is happening. You look great so I’m thrilled about that but I also don’t want to just rely on the PSA and whatever to see what’s happening so CAT scan, chest, abdomen, and pelvis. Patient: Same thing I had before. Doctor: And bone scan, same thing. Now, let’s fast forward so we don’t freak out that if it’s worse, and you know my definition of worse is not the stuff went away that’s back, it’s just do I see more things or black spots on your bone scan. Your bone scan doesn’t changed much as you know. It kind of looks perpetually icky based on your original so you haven’t changed this whole time. I’m looking to see if there’s new spots in the leg or anywhere else. Now that I know you have pain and discomfort there, I of course look there to make sure there is nothing new there. Patient: Well, this only started when I… Doctor: Yeah, so you know… Patient: I’ve been having pain in my back but I had that. That’s when my back was hurting then right after that it was found out that I the cancer and they went ahead so. Doctor: Right, yeah, so we’ll just follow to make sure it’s nothing new, anything new that pops up and of course you’re getting the CAT scan because I want to make sure there’s nothing new in the liver or the lungs or anything as well. I’m not expecting it to but we have to check. Now, if your PSA is just, you know, creeping up, which it kind of is, I know. Patient: It went up. Doctor: Yeah, it did, it did. You’re actually at, wait, you were…. Patient: I was at 19.

Patient: Oh yeah, yeah. Doctor: Maybe it will cool down a little bit. Patient: Yeah right, yeah. Doctor: But let’s not do it too fast because remember even before this when we tried to get you off of it… Patient: Yeah I had issues. Doctor: You had a major revolt. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So let’s take it really slow. Family Member: The only issue he had he was nervous at first it might be his kidneys he was having a pain on this side, but then it switches to the other side. So I think it’s his back. Patient: I think it’s my back. Family Member: Yea, because it went from… Doctor: Does it hurt now when I push? Patient: No, no, no.

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So January thirtieth. Family Member: Okay, right. Doctor: So everything else that we’re going to add up now will be related to the study. Family Member: Okay. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. Um and yeah, you’ve got the visit with Dr___, and his team – Family Member: Catheter Doctor: - to change the catheter – Patient: Right. Doctor: - but if you don’t need that because you’re doing it locally - Patient: Right.

Family Member: The doctor didn’t even want to – he wouldn’t prescribe it, then he did prescribe it and we went to the pharmacy and they said we don’t carry it. Patient: But he directed us to an over-the-counter thing that worked really well. So that helped a lot. Doctor: It must have been scopolamine or something. Family Member: Yeah it was for anti-nausea. Patient: Anyway so I understand I have one point four from point four? Doctor: Yes. So the PSA is going up and the scans are showing slight worsening. Patient: I thought you said the scans didn’t… Family Member: That’s what you said last month. Healthcare Professional: Last time they had the prelim report, but… Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So one of the areas and again like I said I don’t know what to make of this because it is on the bone scan. I thought I – did we talk about this? Okay. Family Member: Last time you said they were absolutely the same. One hundred perc- (nervous laugh)

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.1 time: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::1 time

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.agree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::agree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.strongly agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::strongly agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.strongly agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::strongly agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.strongly agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::strongly agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed
Which of the following best describe you.Student: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Student

What is the highest grade or level of s.12 years or completed high school: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::12 years or completed high school

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian

displayed_text: Patient: They ain’t doin’ any… (pause4sec) Doctor: And pain wise I have to give you the one hundred eighty right? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I think you’ve reminded me after now enough that (laughs) Healthcare Professional: I think he’s on morphine sixty? Doctor: Is he authorized for the Okay. Patient: Oh out here? Doctor: No or when you go over for treatment you can hand it to your nurse Patient: Okay. Doctor: and they can make all the schedule for you. Patient: Oh. Doctor: So you don’t have to wait here. Patient: Right.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Okay and uh then we’ll plan for your appointment after the cryo and everything is done. So forget about the June appointment. We’ll just schedule something later on. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay because probably the whole month of June will be taken up so most likely it will be somewhere end of July or so. Okay? Patient: So how do I make the appointment for the scope? Doctor: Yeah I’m gonna tell them so the scheduler will hook you up or J the nurse will talk to the scheduler. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You’ll either know today or they may have to call you once they put you on the schedule. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Family Member: And then how long after that scope thing? Doctor: Usually then he’ll pick a date so. Family Member: Oh okay.
